title: Beginner here, Is feeling tension (pressure) in the brain when trying to live in the present (i.e., when practicing mindfulness) normal, or am I doing it wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s a story about some western visitors at a Japanese Zen temple. They asked the abbot all sorts of questions about meditation, and he gave very full and detailed answers. Eventually, somebody asked, “is effort required?” He said only: “That’s a difficult question.”  It’s similar with mindfulness practice. You’re not asked to cause yourself any stress and tension, but many beginners will find it takes a bit of effort to allow it to become effortless.. It’s called Mindfulness Practice for a reason! When you’re learning a new skill, you don’t get it right every time. Don’t worry about that! You won’t be present all the time - that’s normal. It’s expected. The practise is simply to bring yourself gently back to the the present once you notice your mind is wandering. It might help to think of mindful, relaxed presence as your natural state. The practice is to stop doing the things that take you away from presence, whenever you notice them. You don’t need to stand guard over yourself or monitor yourself rigidly. Just set an intention to be present, and gently remind yourself to return to presence when you notice you have become distracted. Beginners sometimes picture a “boss” part of their mind keeping a close eye on an unruly “prisoner” mind … but that will make you very tense and drive you crazy. There’s nothing wrong with having thoughts or memories or daydreams - you’ve just decided to try something else for a little while.  If you have a day when you find yourself distracted all the time, and you bring yourself back to the present a thousand times? Fabulous! That’s a great workout! It will gradually make it easier for you to stay present and relaxed. Be gentle with yourselfLet goIt’s not a raceEveryone gets distracted. It’s OKTreat your mind like a cute infant or a puppy dog learning to stay in one place. Just gently and kindly remind it to return when it wanders off.Your responsibility in Mindfulness is simply to respond to distraction - not to prevent it from happening. As long as you are alive, your brain will secrete distracting thoughts in the same way your pancreas secretes insulin. Gradually, you’ll learn not to be controlled by them.  And while you’re practising, when you find yourself being frustrated with your distracted mind - just notice the frustrated feeling. Over time, gradually, gently, you’ll develop the ability to be mindful for longer: without tension and without forcing and without frustration.

You’re doing it right. There’s no way you can get it wrong, so long as you realize you’re not trying to get anywhere, or arrive at any destination. Experience is feedback presented by you to you. It’s purpose: it shows you what’s next. Without it, without experience, how would you know where you are relative to where you started? Introducing the belief contained in the word “wrong” and the negative feeling you may feel having judged your practice, are both also feedback. A good rule of thumb to post on your mental refrigerator is: if it feels good it is good. If it doesn’t feel good, that’s good too! Take the feedback and adjust. Physical manifestations of discomfort can mean a lot of things. It might help turning your attention to that pressure and nonjudgmentally be with it. After all, you’re practicing being in the present/mindfulness and tension is part of your now, so what better thing to put attention on to focus you in your now/be present? You may discover too what you’re calling “tension” turns to something else under your dispassionate internal gaze. Finally, relax. You’re eternal. You have all of eternity to bring greater awareness to the now. There’s no rush. You never get it wrong. So enjoy the process on your way to greater expansion/awareness. 👍🏾

If you are feeling tension when you try to live in the present, you are doing it wrong. The right way to practice Mindfulness is: First join a retreat with an experienced teacher for at least 10 days or 2 weeksYou shall learn to do sitting meditation and walking meditationWalking meditation is to bring the Mindfulness from sitting to all aspects of life, like eating, cooking, driving, studying and walkingYou cannot practice Mindfulness from just reading some materials, especially those that is written in the west and then try to enforce it into your life. Until you can join a retreat, you can now start to notice how often you watch your breath or your thoughts or your feelings and sensations in your body, especially in your free time. The more you do this, the better. If your mind wanders, i.e. thinking, chattering, etc…, gently bring it back to watch your breath, thoughts or feelings from moment to moment without joining in the mental chit chat. Don’t try, just remind yourself to do this. You can read more books of Zon-Kabat Zinn on the subject. Wish you good practice

Youre doing it right and you should see these new sensations as markers of progress… often when practicing those who are awakening begin experiencing sensations all over the body including pressure an headache like sensations… when being present and watching the breath youre increasing your brains oxygen supply which will cause you to experience loads of funny sensations… weird tinglings and head pressure and the like… vibrations hot cold sensations etc. Youre rewiring the neural circuitry of your brain and this is what happens. Your brain will work much harder the more you train yourself in mindfulness and that can create headache like effects but keep going its a good sign. When I pull all day mediation sessions sometimes my head throbs to the point of bursting and its difficult for me to even turn my head to the left or right… this is a side effect of “machine consciousness” and when those gears start turning you bring the pain lol

I always tell myself don't try too hard because it can backfire.. To answer your question a little bit of tension is good but when it gets out of control it can cause a mental strain.. Your brain is like a muscle, you train it then it becomes stronger then before.( Remember this) You wanna try but not try to hard.. Like learning to box you just simply go with the motions but don't think too hard about it.. Trust me if you do it like this then it will work. Or you can always ask your higher mind this question and it will give you an easy to understand answer.

The practice of mindfulness helps us to be in the present, so you are on the right track there. But, don’t make it like a chore or a duty. Also, don’t feel guilty if you forget the practice from time to time. As long as you notice it and come back to the awareness of present moment, that is fine. Of course, continuity of awareness of present is good, but it takes time, and with practice and patience, it gets better. Good luck.

Make sure to include your body in your mindfulness. In fact, let it be a point of concentration for a little while. You may be experiencing something related to posture. Pay attention to what you feel and where you feel it. Is your back and neck straight and aligned? Is your head bowed forward too much? I suspect you can discover the source through careful attention. Should this not work, of course, as already said, consult a doctor.

Is it you who is practicing mindfulness then it is wrong practice.? The purpose of mindfulness in Buddhism is to understand ALL realities as not self, not belonging you. This is deep, difficult and subtle. Nobody can make mindfulness arise and nobody can stop it from arising. It is conditioned to arise. The skilled understanding of the Buddha’s word is the condition. It is not a matter of doing anything but the difference between when there is mindfulness and not mindfulness can be understood.

It's normal to experience a wide variety of sensations and feelings while practicing mindfulness. I would carry on with your practice because it will change. I don't know if you are doing it right so perhaps you could write back explaining what you are doing. I have done the teacher training for mindfulness so I can direct you with confidence on that matter. 🙏🙏

There are two directions to experiment toward the reality of the present from our brain or toward our brain from reality like in mindfulness. The second,indfulness prequires an effort while the first is natural and doesn t require really an effort.

Depends. If it is not related with something else than focusing in the present action, then it is normal: you keep your mind forcibly in the present, without an instrument. If you will use an instrument, such as japa, you will be much better.

Many things can happen and awareness, meditation, mindfulness will have different effects on each person. If you’re worried, see a doctor otherwise simply watch and witness what’s going on without judgement. This too will pass.
Just work through it. Tip - do not force things to happen just allow them to happen- that is passive volition.
Initially mind don’t like to do meditation so bring many thoughts cause tension so continue meditation slowly it will be normalized.
